--- title: "Summarizing Categorical Data" format: revealjs: author: "STAT 20: Introduction to Probability and Statistics" height: 900 width: 1600 theme: ../../assets/slides.scss multiplex: false transition: fade slide-number: c incremental: false center: false menu: false highlight-style: github progress: false code-overflow: wrap title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: ../../assets/stat20-hex-bg.png data-background-size: contain --- ## Agenda - Concept Questions: Taxonomy of Data - Reading Questions - Practice Problems - *Break* - Lab 1: Getting Started ## The Goal of Lab Session - Best way to make progress on these assignments - You likely will need to work outside of class to finish the assignment - Visit Evening Study Session Thurs & Mon 6:30 - 8:30 pm to work with peers and get help from tutors - Also ask questions on the Lab thread on Ed ## Arbuthnot :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} **Who**: John Arbuthnot, Scottish mathematician/physician **When**: 1710 **Where**: London, England **Why**: Try to determine the ratio of the sexes of children at birth; i.e. what is the chance that a newly born child is female? **How**: Collecting christening records from all of the parish churches in London. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/thames.png) ::: :::: ## What is a christening record? . . . A Christening is a ceremony/rite in the Church of England where: 1. The parents bring their new born child to a priest at the church. 2. As part of the ceremony, the parents give a first name to the child before the child is baptized (inducted into the church). 3. The name of the child and their parents are recorded in a ledger. . . . John Arbuthnot tabulated the total count of names in each year that were traditionally female and male names. ## {data-menu-title="Christening Records" background-image="images/christening-records.png" background-size=contain} ## {data-menu-title="Christening Records Zoomed" background-image="images/christening-records-zoom.png" background-size=contain} ## Preparing your assignment Something about a qmd ## Part I: Understanding the Context of the Data 1. What question did John Arbuthnot set out to answer in collecting this data? 2. What is the unit of observation in the original christening records? What are the possible variables that may have been recorded? 3. What do you think the probability is that a newborn child is recorded as a girl? What form of evidence or reasoning did you use to come to that determination? ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
03:00
``` ::: ::: # Computational Tools for Part II and III ## Loading Data from a Package R packages offer a convenient way to store data. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell .fragment} ```{.r .cell-code} ?penguins ``` ::: . . . - Load packages with `library()` - Load data with `data()` - Some data comes pre-loaded and doesn't require `data()` (e.g. `mtcars`) ## Functions on data frames The `tidyverse` package contains several functions used to manipulate data frames: - `select()` : subset columns . . . - `arrange()` : sort rows . . . - `mutate()` : create a new column from existing column(s) ## Selecting columns ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} select(penguins, species, island) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 344 × 2 species island 1 Adelie Torgersen 2 Adelie Torgersen 3 Adelie Torgersen 4 Adelie Torgersen 5 Adelie Torgersen 6 Adelie Torgersen 7 Adelie Torgersen 8 Adelie Torgersen 9 Adelie Torgersen 10 Adelie Torgersen # … with 334 more rows ``` ::: ::: # Arranging the data frame by a column ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} arrange(penguins, bill_length_mm) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 344 × 8 species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_…¹ body_…² sex year 1 Adelie Dream 32.1 15.5 188 3050 fema… 2009 2 Adelie Dream 33.1 16.1 178 2900 fema… 2008 3 Adelie Torgersen 33.5 19 190 3600 fema… 2008 4 Adelie Dream 34 17.1 185 3400 fema… 2008 5 Adelie Torgersen 34.1 18.1 193 3475 2007 6 Adelie Torgersen 34.4 18.4 184 3325 fema… 2007 7 Adelie Biscoe 34.5 18.1 187 2900 fema… 2008 8 Adelie Torgersen 34.6 21.1 198 4400 male 2007 9 Adelie Torgersen 34.6 17.2 189 3200 fema… 2008 10 Adelie Biscoe 35 17.9 190 3450 fema… 2008 # … with 334 more rows, and abbreviated variable names ¹​flipper_length_mm, # ²​body_mass_g ``` ::: ::: . . . > You can sort in descending order by wrapping the variable name in `desc()`. # Mutating a new column . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mutate(penguins, bill_index = bill_depth_mm + bill_length_mm) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 344 × 9 species island bill_length_mm bill_d…¹ flipp…² body_…³ sex year bill_…⁴ 1 Adelie Torgersen 39.1 18.7 181 3750 male 2007 57.8 2 Adelie Torgersen 39.5 17.4 186 3800 fema… 2007 56.9 3 Adelie Torgersen 40.3 18 195 3250 fema… 2007 58.3 4 Adelie Torgersen NA NA NA NA 2007 NA 5 Adelie Torgersen 36.7 19.3 193 3450 fema… 2007 56 6 Adelie Torgersen 39.3 20.6 190 3650 male 2007 59.9 7 Adelie Torgersen 38.9 17.8 181 3625 fema… 2007 56.7 8 Adelie Torgersen 39.2 19.6 195 4675 male 2007 58.8 9 Adelie Torgersen 34.1 18.1 193 3475 2007 52.2 10 Adelie Torgersen 42 20.2 190 4250 2007 62.2 # … with 334 more rows, and abbreviated variable names ¹​bill_depth_mm, # ²​flipper_length_mm, ³​body_mass_g, ⁴​bill_index ``` ::: ::: . . . > Remember that you can nest functions. # Mutating a new column . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} select(mutate(penguins, bill_index = bill_depth_mm + bill_length_mm), bill_index) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 344 × 1 bill_index 1 57.8 2 56.9 3 58.3 4 NA 5 56 6 59.9 7 56.7 8 58.8 9 52.2 10 62.2 # … with 334 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Part II: Computing on the Data . . . - Load the `arbuthnot` data frame in the `stat20data` package. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(stat20data) data(arbuthnot) ``` ::: - Work on questions 4 - 7, editing your Google Doc as you go. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
10:00
``` ::: ::: ## Your first plot . . . A template for a line plot: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(DATAFRAME, aes(x = XVARIABLE, y = YVARIABLE)) + geom_line() ``` ::: Where: - `DATAFRAME` is the name of your data frame - `XVARIABLE` is the name of the variable of that data frame that you want on the x-axis - `YVARIABLE` is the name of the variable of that data frmae that you want on the y-axis > These plots can be copy-and-pasted into your Google Doc by clicking on the "Export" button next to the plot in RStudio ## Part III: Extensions How do trends in a more modern data set compare to Arbuthnot's data? Find out in the `present` data frame found in the `stat20data` package. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data(present) ?present ``` :::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {

      // dispatch for htmlwidgets
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for reveal
    if (window.Reveal) {
      window.Reveal.addEventListener("slidechanged", function(event) {
        fireSlideChanged(event.previousSlide, event.currentSlide);
      });
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
